Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC: Net-Centric SoftwareSystems Center Site at Missouri University of Science and Technology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed planning activity seeks to establish a new Industry/University Cooperative Research Center (I/UCRC) site at Missouri University of Science and Technology of the existing Net-Centric Software Systems Center. The center currently involves two universities University of North Texas and the University of Texas Dallas. The specific needs within the Center to be met by Missouri University of Science and Technology are focused in the areas of data compression, security, software code optimization, 3D IC for reduced latency and battery optimization for small form factors. These areas complement those of the two existing sites of the center and offer opportunities for collaborative work.

The proposed new site, in combination with the existing center plans to build innovation capacity by enhancing knowledge of the scientific community and industrial members in the area of Net-Centric computing and wireless technologies. Member commitment letters indicate the potential for significant impact with industrial members. The site plans to impact students via their involvement in center research experiences and outreach to local schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Net-Centric Software and Systems Center performed scientific and applied research in the areas of network centric computing in the domain of pervasive & mobile computing, cloud computing Security, battery and hardware design for small devices at the Missouri S & T site. The projects were sponsored by AFRL, Hengsoft. Streber-Tech, and Jianghuan Petroleum.  The center developed a highly capable and elastically scalable index structure to support multidimensional data and efficient point, range and k-nearest neighbor (KNN) query processing in a cloud based system. Another project designed a scheme to close the gap between noise sensor designs and noise management systems by putting forward a systematic framework for best noise management efficacy. In yet another project, it developed a systematic and efficient design flow for optimal three-dimensional integrated circuits (3D IC) designs by exploring the tradeoff between power, area, latency and reliability (thermal, mechanical, etc.) using through-silicon-vias (TSVs) as the tuning knob.  A data pre-distribution scheme for efficient sharing of data among potential users in mobile cloud computing environment, update propagation and cache replacement policies were designed and implemented. Dynamic Multi-Replica Provable Data Possession scheme (DMR-PDP) that prevents the Cloud Service Provider from cheating by maintaining fewer copies was also designed. DMR-PDP also supports dynamic operations like block modification, insertion, and deletion and append on replicas over cloud servers. In another project, it developed a localized battery management systems (BMS) that completely eliminates the central controller used in most battery management systems (BMS) today. An approach that reduces the run time overhead by performing most of the query optimization at compile time for the first class query constructs written explicitly in programs were also developed. These industry sponsored projects helped many other consortium members and other rsearchers. PhDs, MSs and undergraduate students worked on these projects and got their degrees. Several top journal and conferences research papers were published. Many presentations on the work were also given at different venues for wider dissemination of the outcomes including some of the results were presented in the graduate classes and in the training of undergraduate students as part of the NSF REU site.
